title: Possible SQL injection on "Jump to twitter"

profile.name: Gratipay
profile.about: Gratitude? Gratipay! The easiest way for your company to pay for open source.

vulnerability_information: The https://gratipay.com/on/twitter/'  (single-quote at the end) request returns 500 Error, but https://gratipay.com/on/twitter/" returns 404 so i believe it may be an injection. To find the url, go to /search and jump to ' twitter.
vulnerability_information_html: The https://gratipay.com/on/twitter/' (single-quote at the end) request returns 500 Error, but https://gratipay.com/on/twitter/" returns 404 so i believe it may be an injection. To find the url, go to /search and jump to ' twitter.

activities.message: Thanks for the report, @nikitakun. I doubt it's an injection, because we protect against SQL injection at a low level in our call stack for database access. Both URLs should be a 404, though, so we should at least fix the 500 for the first URL. Marking as triaged for now ...
activities.markdown_message: Thanks for the report, @nikitakun. I doubt it's an injection, because we protect against SQL injection at a low level in our call stack for database access. Both URLs should be a 404, though, so we should at least fix the 500 for the first URL. Marking as triaged for now ...

activities.message: P.S. I invite you to review [our code](https://github.com/gratipay/gratipay.com) and determine whether an injection is in fact happening.
activities.markdown_message: P.S. I invite you to review our code and determine whether an injection is in fact happening.

activities.message:
Oh, nice, didn't know it's open-source :)
I've looked at it, haven't found the reason yet. I'll try a bit later.

By the way, the error only appears when searching profiles on twitter, not on github/bitbucket/etc. Hope that helps.

activities.message: The 404 is cool. That's because there's no Twitter user with username ".
activities.markdown_message: The 404 is cool. That's because there's no Twitter user with username ".

activities.message:
We're [making](https://github.com/gratipay/gratipay.com/blob/1940/gratipay/elsewhere/__init__.py#L118) an API call with this [path](https://github.com/gratipay/gratipay.com/blob/1940/gratipay/elsewhere/twitter.py#L26) ([formatted](https://github.com/gratipay/gratipay.com/blob/1940/gratipay/elsewhere/__init__.py#L241)):

```python
'/users/show.json?screen_name={user_name}'.format(user_name="'")
```

That's what's triggering the 500 down in oauthlib.
activities.markdown_message:
We're making an API call with this path (formatted):

'/users/show.json?screen_name={user_name}'.format(user_name="'")

That's what's triggering the 500 down in oauthlib.

activities.message: I suppose the fix is to percent-encode the values we use to format the paths we hit.
activities.markdown_message: I suppose the fix is to percent-encode the values we use to format the paths we hit.

activities.message: So this isn't a SQL injection, but it *could* be an OAuth injection.
activities.markdown_message: So this isn't a SQL injection, but it could be an OAuth injection.

activities.message: PR at https://github.com/gratipay/security/pull/2.
activities.markdown_message: PR at https://github.com/gratipay/security/pull/2.

activities.message: PR is ready for review.
activities.markdown_message: PR is ready for review.

activities.message:
```diff
diff --git a/gratipay/elsewhere/__init__.py b/gratipay/elsewhere/__init__.py
index b510e1c..349ece5 100644
--- a/gratipay/elsewhere/__init__.py
+++ b/gratipay/elsewhere/__init__.py
@@ -238,7 +238,7 @@ def get_user_info(self, key, value, sess=None):
         path = getattr(self, path, None)
         if not path:
             raise Response(400)
-        path = path.format(**{key: value})
+        path = path.format(**{key: quote(value)})
         info = self.api_parser(self.api_get(path, sess=sess))
         return self.extract_user_info(info)
 
diff --git a/tests/py/test_elsewhere.py b/tests/py/test_elsewhere.py
index a3226fb..ecc48eb 100644
--- a/tests/py/test_elsewhere.py
+++ b/tests/py/test_elsewhere.py
@@ -31,6 +31,11 @@ def test_extract_user_info(self):
             assert r.user_id is not None
             assert len(r.user_id) > 0
 
+    @mock.patch('gratipay.elsewhere.Platform.api_get')
+    def test_get_user_info_quotes_values(self, api_get):
+        self.platforms.twitter.get_user_info('user_name', "'")
+        api_get.assert_called_with("/users/show.json?screen_name=%27", sess=None)
+
     def test_opt_in_can_change_username(self):
         account = self.make_elsewhere('twitter', 1, 'alice')
         expected = 'bob'
```
activities.markdown_message:
diff --git a/gratipay/elsewhere/__init__.py b/gratipay/elsewhere/__init__.py
index b510e1c..349ece5 100644
--- a/gratipay/elsewhere/__init__.py
+++ b/gratipay/elsewhere/__init__.py
@@ -238,7 +238,7 @@ def get_user_info(self, key, value, sess=None):
         path = getattr(self, path, None)
         if not path:
             raise Response(400)
-        path = path.format(**{key: value})
+        path = path.format(**{key: quote(value)})
         info = self.api_parser(self.api_get(path, sess=sess))
         return self.extract_user_info(info)

diff --git a/tests/py/test_elsewhere.py b/tests/py/test_elsewhere.py
index a3226fb..ecc48eb 100644
--- a/tests/py/test_elsewhere.py
+++ b/tests/py/test_elsewhere.py
@@ -31,6 +31,11 @@ def test_extract_user_info(self):
             assert r.user_id is not None
             assert len(r.user_id) > 0

+    @mock.patch('gratipay.elsewhere.Platform.api_get')
+    def test_get_user_info_quotes_values(self, api_get):
+        self.platforms.twitter.get_user_info('user_name', "'")
+        api_get.assert_called_with("/users/show.json?screen_name=%27", sess=None)
+
     def test_opt_in_can_change_username(self):
         account = self.make_elsewhere('twitter', 1, 'alice')
         expected = 'bob'

activities.message:
Weird. We've discovered a HackerOne markdown rendering bug:

```
@ foo
```

Put the `@` and the `foo` together and instead of `@foo` we get `[@foo](/foo)`:

```
@foo
```

Is this exploitable? :-)
activities.markdown_message:

Put the @ and the foo together and instead of @foo we get [@foo](/foo):

Is this exploitable? :-)

activities.message: This certainly isn't a SQL injection, and in general does not appear to be an exploitable vulnerability. I think we should reticket in public GitHub and close here.

activities.message: On second thought, not quoting values before sending them over oauth does seem to be a bad idea. I've added a commit to [PR-2](https://github.com/gratipay/security/pull/2) to raise 404 instead of 500 for the Bitbucket case we're seeing. How's that, @aandis?
activities.markdown_message: On second thought, not quoting values before sending them over oauth does seem to be a bad idea. I've added a commit to PR-2 to raise 404 instead of 500 for the Bitbucket case we're seeing. How's that, @aandis?
